headline.main: Beirut Journal; TV Chef Adds World of Flavors to Arab Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: For their annual feast marking the end of Ramadan, the Teffaha household boldly decided to defy tradition, scratching stuffed lamb off the menu and penciling in a roast turkey. The problem was how to cook it. Riffling through old Lebanese cookbooks failed to unearth a recipe. No one in their building had ever tried to cook a bird. Then an excited neighbor called one day at noon and yelled that they should turn on the television immediately, because Chef Ramzi was preparing that very thing.

headline.main: For Eclectic, Ethnic Asian Cuisine: A World of Flavors in Singapore

docs.abstract: Nina Simonds Choice Tables review of ethnic restaurants in Singapore; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: I USED to avoid Singapore, dismissing it as a somewhat sterile, westernized city that had little to offer in the way of authentic Asian cooking. Instead, I traveled to Hong Kong, for years Asia's leading culinary mecca. But times have changed: Move over Hong Kong and make room for Singapore. About 10 years ago, I spent four days in Singapore, and was stunned by the eclectic selection of dishes. That was the beginning of a love affair, and I now return each year.

headline.main: Streetscapes/Duane Park in TriBeCa; From Butter and Eggs to the Home of Haute Cuisine

docs.abstract: David Bouley is establishing a muntifaceted culinary complex around Duane Park in lower Manhattan, a section of city that started out residential, converted to commercial use toward end of 19th century and has recently witnessed conversion of commercial buildings to co-op loft space; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ON Duane Park, a doorman has arrived just as the last of the butter-and-egg men is leaving. At the same time, the triangle around the park, built up in the 1880's as a commercial food district, is expected to become, thanks to the restaurateur David Bouley, a center of haute cuisine in residential TriBeCa. According to research by the TriBeCa historian Oliver Allen, Duane Park was planted as a formal garden as early as 1804, as a complement to the Federal-style buildings going up on its perimeter. These were mostly single-family row houses, like the building at 171 Duane Street put up in 1803 for Henry Verveelen, a schoolmaster. Although the house has been reconstructed, traces of its Jefferson-era windows stick out from the Staple Street side.

headline.main: At the Nation's Table: Johnson, Ark.;From Down Home To Ozark Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: When Miles James was dreaming up the menu for his year-old restaurant, James at the Mill, in Johnson, Ark., his wife, Courtney, told him one morning, "You were saying corn dog in your sleep." He took that to heart. Today, Mr. James has elevated the down-home foods he grew up with and made his dream come true: his homemade andouille sausage corn dog stands straight up on the plate, ringed by brown Sun Valley mustard, capers and red bliss mash. Height seems to be something of a theme at the pioneering restaurant three miles north of Fayetteville; a tall, varnished sycamore tree is sunk in the bilevel dining room's foundation, its branches reaching to the ceiling.

headline.main: Chefs in U.S. Must Recognize Demand for Vegetarian Cuisine; Change Your Cookbook

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Speaking as one young woman who bows to "rampant vegetarianism," as Zachary M. Schrag puts it (letter, Jan. 28), I must protest; "only steamed vegetables and plain pasta" is not a fair estimation of vegetarian cuisine. If Mr. Schrag wants to impress vegetarians of his generation, he might try his hand at black bean chili, stuffed eggplant, vegetable strudel, ratatouille or asparagus souffle. Before he passes judgment on vegetarian diets as insipid and uninspired, he should consider getting a new cookbook, rather than a carnivorous girlfriend. DEBORAH R. LEVY New York, Jan. 28, 1992
